title: English (1912) Self Interpreting Study Bible (Vol. 1-4)
description:
The 1912 edition of John Brown of Haddington's 'Self-interpreting Bible,' first published in 1778, is a remarkable work designed to make the scriptures accessible to the 'poorer and labouring part of mankind.' Brown's intent was to encapsulate the insights of esteemed biblical commentators in a format that resonates with the common reader, effectively making the Bible its own best interpreter. This comprehensive compilation includes historical context, chronological timelines, geographical references, concise summaries, and explanatory notes, all aimed at demystifying the Bible's content.

Brown's approach is characterized by his readiness to offer definitive explanations for each verse and to draw practical lessons applicable to everyday life. His writing style is noted for its clarity and vigor, making complex theological concepts accessible to a broad audience. The 'Self-interpreting Bible' quickly gained widespread popularity, becoming a staple in many English-speaking households, including those in Wales and the Scottish Highlands.

This work stands as a testament to Brown's dedication to biblical scholarship and his commitment to making biblical knowledge available to all, regardless of their educational background or social status. It serves not only as a religious guide but also as a comprehensive resource, offering a deep and practical understanding of the Bible's teachings. The 'Self-interpreting Bible' remains a significant contribution to the field of biblical studies and continues to be valued for its insightful and approachable commentary on the scriptures.
